    Overview of Ordomatic

    Now that you know what is an ordo, here are the main lines of how Ordomatic works.

    As we have said, an ordo is the superposition of two calendars: the Temporal and the Sanctoral. So you will have to give to Ordomatic a list of "Temporal-days" and a list of "Sanctoral-days", each one of them with a number giving their force. This number will allow Ordomatic to compare each day of the Temporal and the Sanctoral and determines which one to chose for a given date. You will have to indicate too, for each one of these days, a "header" and a "body", that is, the title and the content of each day, which will appear in the final ordo. Finally, for each day of the Temporal, you will have to give a "baseline" (among "start", "easter" and "end") and a "number of days" separating this day from the baseline (for example, the Palm Sunday's baseline is "Easter" and the distance is "-7").

    Perhaps an example will be more clear…

    A first example

    Let's say that you have entered in Ordomatic (we will see later how) these Temporal-days, the 7 first ones of a liturgical year:

    Name Force Baseline Days Header Body
    First Sunday of Advent 120 Start 0 First Sunday of Advent Body of first Sunday of Advent, bla bla…
    First Monday of Advent 20 Start 1 Monday after first Sunday of Advent Body of first Monday of Advent, bla bla…
    First Tuesday of Advent 20 Start 2 Tuesday after first Sunday of Advent Body of first Tuesday of Advent, bla bla…
    First Wednedsday of Advent 20 Start 3 Wednesday after first Sunday of Advent Body of first Wednedsday of Advent, bla bla…
    First Thursday of Advent 20 Start 4 Thursday after first Sunday of Advent Body of first Thursday of Advent, bla bla…
    First Friday of Advent 20 Start 5 Friday after first Sunday of Advent Body of first Friday of Advent, bla bla…
    First Saturday of Advent 20 Start 6 Saturday after first Sunday of Advent Body of first Saturday of Advent, bla bla…

    And here are your super Sanctoral-days:

    Name Force Header Body
    Saint Andrew (30 November) 70 Saint Andrew, Feast Body of saint Andrew, bla bla…
    Saint Franciscus Xavier (3 December) 40 Saint Franciscus Xavier, Memory Body of saint Franciscus Xavier, bla bla…

    Now let's say that this year, the first Sunday of Advent is on 29 November (like in year 2020-2021). The first lines of your ordo will look like that:

    November

    Sun, 29 - First Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Sunday of Advent, bla bla…

    Mon, 30 - Saint Andrew, Feast

    Body of saint Andrew, bla bla…

    December

    Tue, 1 - Tuesday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Tuesday of Advent, bla bla…

    Wed, 2 - Wednesday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Wednesday of Advent, bla bla…

    Thu, 3 - Saint Franciscus Xavier, Memory

    Body of saint Franciscus Xavier, bla bla…

    Fri, 4 - Friday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Friday of Advent, bla bla…

    Sat, 5 - Saturday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Saturday of Advent, bla bla…

    What has happened?

    Ordomatic has calculated 3 "baselines". A "baseline" is a date from which other dates will be calculated. For example, from "easter" baseline, you get all the dates of the Lent time and the dates of the Easter time. For the liturgical year 2021, the 3 baselines are:

    • "start" = Sunday 29 November
    • "easter" = Sunday 4 April
    • "end" = Sunday 28 November ("end" of year y = "start" of year y + 1)

    The first baseline ("start") is the most important for our example, as we haven't entered Temporal-days that have "easter" or "end" as a baseline.

    After having calculated the date of "start" baseline, Ordomatic has searched in your list of Temporal-days all the days that have "start" as a baseline. He has found 7 days (those which we have entered in the table above) and he has determined at which date they happen for the liturgical year 2021, according to the field "Days" of each one of them:

    • "First Sunday of Advent" = "start" + 0 days = Sunday 29 November
    • "First Monday of Advent" = "start" + 1 days = Monday 30 November
    • "First Tuesday of Advent" = "start" + 2 days = Tuesday 1 December
    • "First Wednesday of Advent" = "start" + 3 days = Wednesday 2 December
    • "First Thursday of Advent" = "start" + 4 days = Thursday 3 December
    • "First Friday of Advent" = "start" + 5 days = Friday 4 December
    • "First Saturday of Advent" = "start" + 6 days = Saturday 5 December

    At this step, Ordomatic can output your ordo, but with the Temporal-days only, thanks to the data you have entered above. Your ordo would look like that:

    November

    Sun, 29 - First Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Sunday of Advent, bla bla…

    Mon, 30 - Monday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Monday of Advent, bla bla…

    December

    Tue, 1 - Tuesday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Tuesday of Advent, bla bla…

    Wed, 2 - Wednesday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Wednesday of Advent, bla bla…

    Thu, 3 - Thursday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Thursday of Advent, bla bla…

    Fri, 4 - Friday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Friday of Advent, bla bla…

    Sat, 5 - Saturday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Saturday of Advent, bla bla…

    At a second step, Ordomatic has searched, for each one of the calculated date (29 November 2021, 30 November 2021 etc.) if a day in your Sanctoral-days had the corresponding month and day. He has founded 2: Saint Andrew and saint Franciscus Xavier.

    Then he has compared the respective forces of the Temporal-days and of the Sanctoral-days:

    Date Temporal Sanctoral Winner!
    Sunday 29 November First Sunday of Advent [120] First Sunday of Advent
    Monday 30 November First Monday of Advent [20] Saint Andrew [70] Saint Andrew
    Tuesday 1 December First Tuesday of Advent [20] First Tuesday of Advent
    Wednesday 2 December First Wednedsday of Advent [20] First Wednedsday of Advent
    Thursday 3 December First Thursday of Advent [20] Saint Franciscus Xavier [40] Saint Franciscus Xavier
    Friday 4 December First Friday of Advent [20] First Friday of Advent
    Saturday 5 December First Saturday of Advent [20] First Saturday of Advent

    Hence the output that you can see above.

    Another example

    Let's say that another year, the first Sunday of Advent is on 30 November (like in year 2014-2015). This time, the comparison of Temporal and Sanctoral will be:

    Date Temporal Sanctoral Winner!
    Sunday 30 November First Sunday of Advent [120] Saint Andrew [70] First Sunday of Advent
    Monday 1 December First Monday of Advent [20] First Monday of Advent
    Tuesday 2 December First Tuesday of Advent [20] First Tuesday of Advent
    Wednesday 3 December First Wednedsday of Advent [20] Saint Franciscus Xavier [40] Saint Franciscus Xavier
    Thursday 4 December First Thursday of Advent [20] First Thursday of Advent
    Friday 5 December First Friday of Advent [20] First Friday of Advent
    Saturday 6 December First Saturday of Advent [20] First Saturday of Advent

    And the first lines of your ordo would look like that:

    November

    Sun, 30 - First Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Sunday of Advent, bla bla…

    December

    Mon, 1 - Monday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Monday of Advent, bla bla…

    Tue, 2 - Tuesday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Tuesday of Advent, bla bla…

    Wed, 3 - Saint Franciscus Xavier, Memory

    Body of saint Franciscus Xavier, bla bla…

    Thu, 4 - Thursday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Thursday of Advent, bla bla…

    Fri, 5 - Friday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Friday of Advent, bla bla…

    Sat, 6 - Saturday after first Sunday of Advent

    Body of first Saturday of Advent, bla bla…

    Summary

    • Ordomatic expects that you give to him a list of Tempral-days and of Sanctoral-days.
    • He calculates 3 baselines for a given year.
    • From the baselines, he calculates at which date will occur your Temporal-days.
    • He compares Temporal and Sanctoral days and determines which one of them is the winner, according to their respective forces.
    • Finally he outputs the final ordo, displaying headers and bodies that you have given to him for each Temporal or Sanctoral-day.
